etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French relatif, -ive, from late Latin relativus ‘having reference or relation’ (see relate)

definitions: considered in relation or in proportion to something else

examples.text: the relative effectiveness of the various mechanisms is not known

shortDefinitions: considered in relation or in proportion to something else

definitions: existing or possessing a specified characteristic only in comparison to something else; not absolute

examples.text: she went down the steps into the relative darkness of the dining room
the companies are relative newcomers to computers

shortDefinitions: existing or possessing specified characteristic only in comparison

definitions: denoting a pronoun, determiner, or adverb that refers to an expressed or implied antecedent and attaches a subordinate clause to it, e.g. which, who.
shortDefinitions: denoting pronoun, determiner, or adverb that refers to expressed or implied antecedent and attaches subordinate clause to it

definitions: (of a clause) attached to an antecedent by a relative word.
shortDefinitions: (of clause) attached to antecedent by relative word

definitions: (of major and minor keys) having the same key signature.
shortDefinitions: (of major and minor keys) having same key signature

definitions: (of a service rank) corresponding in grade to another in a different service.
shortDefinitions: (of service rank) corresponding in grade to another in different service

definitions: a person connected by blood or marriage

examples.text: much of my time is spent visiting relatives

shortDefinitions: person connected by blood or marriage

definitions: a species related to another by common origin

examples.text: the plant is a relative of ivy

shortDefinitions: species related to another by common origin

definitions: a relative pronoun, determiner, or adverb.
a term, thing, or concept that is dependent on something else.
shortDefinitions: term or concept which is dependent on something else
